Description: Egyptian terracotta figure of seated child with side knot. Probably ithyphallic Harpocrates, 'enthroned' but head and lower legs are missing. Mould-made and solid. White coating with red paint covering much of the skin areas. Dark red-brown Nile silt fabric with grey core. Abundant fine gold mica, quartz, organics and white inclusions.
Curator's comments: Object owned and held by the Museum of Classical Archaeology, Cambridge. This record is included in the British Museum database as part of the Museum’s Naukratis Project, a research collaboration that aims to virtually re-unite finds from the ancient port city of Naukratis, now distributed over 80 museums worldwide.
Either 140 or 188 written unclearly on back in pencil.

Enthroned ithyphallic Harpocrates with one hand raised. This type was originally produced during the Late Period as a solid figure (British Museum GR 1973,0501.16 and in stone GR 2011,5011.15; Cambridge Fitzwilliam, E.81.1914, Cambridge MCA, NA596) and was subsequently made hollow in the 3rd century BC like other Ptolemaic figures (Bolton Museum 1886.31.23; British Museum GR 1973,0501.56; GR1973,0501.10; GR1973,0501.74). There is a fold above stomach, typical in Late Period statues (but see also Dunand 1990, no.258 from Tanis), and also on Ptah figures from Rhodes (see British Museum GR 1886,0401.1441 from Naukratis). Similar style with fold above stomach on Harpocrates figures of 6th to 4th century BC terracotta examples were found at Naukratis (Bailey 2008, no. 3206, see also 3205 from Smyrna) and figure from Temai el-Amohel (Cairo SR5/6362) and a mould confiscated in Alexandria (Cairo SR4/15902 TR18/1/81/10B). This is most similar to painted limestone figures from Naukratis (British Museum GR 2011,5011.15, see also GR 2011,5011.11). Parallel (later type?) from 3rd century BC Ras el Soda, Alexandria (Himmelmann 1983, 47, 59, pl.23a; Adriani 1952). Adriani, A. 1952, Municipalité d’Alexandrie, Annuaire du Musée Gréco-Romain. Volume III (1940-1950), Alexandria. Dunand, F. 1990. Musée du Louvre. Département des antiquités égyptiennes. Catalogue des terres cuites grécoromaines d'Egypte. Paris. Himmelmann, N. 1983. Alexandria und der Realismus in der griechischen Kunst. Tübingen : E. Wasmuth.
Bibliographic references: Villing et al 2013-2015 / Naukratis: Greeks in Egypt (DC.145) (Phase 1)
